Adam Smith.description: reflecting on and organizing ideas for his book (1) Adam is setting up his workspace, ensuring he has all necessary materials like notebooks, pens, and his laptop) @ the Ville:Adam Smith's house:main room:desk

Arthur Burton.description: studying mixology and experimenting with new cocktail recipes (reviewing mixology books and online resources) @ the Ville:Arthur Burton's apartment:main room:desk

Ayesha Khan.description: conversing about Ayesha Khan and Carlos Gomez discussing poetry techniques, inspirations from Shakespeare, and modern poets such as Sarah Kay and Ocean Vuong who incorporate classical elements into their work. @ <persona> Carlos Gomez
chat: Ayesha Khan
Hi Carlos! It's great to see you here. How's the discussion on poetry techniques going?
Carlos Gomez
Hi Ayesha! It's going well, the discussions are quite engaging. I'm picking up some interesting insights to incorporate into my poetry. How are your classes going?
Ayesha Khan
That's wonderful to hear! My classes are keeping me busy, especially with my senior thesis on Shakespeare’s plays. Have you ever incorporated any Shakespearean techniques into your poetry?
Carlos Gomez

I've definitely been inspired by his work! I occasionally try to incorporate some of his dramatic flair and intricate wordplay into my poetry. It's a challenging but rewarding process. Speaking of techniques, do you have a favorite Shakespearean technique you've been exploring for your thesis?
Ayesha Khan

I'm glad to hear that, Carlos! I've been delving into Shakespeare's use of iambic pentameter and his ability to convey deep emotions through soliloquies. It's fascinating how he uses language to reveal the inner thoughts of his characters. Is there a particular aspect of his writing that you find most challenging to emulate?
Carlos Gomez

I agree, the way he captures the essence of his characters is truly impressive. For me, the most challenging part is emulating his mastery of rhythm while maintaining my own voice. It’s a balancing act I'm still perfecting. Speaking of which, have you come across any modern poets who draw from Shakespeare in interesting ways?
Ayesha Khan

I can see how that would be challenging, Carlos. There are a few modern poets I’ve been reading who have interesting takes. For example, I think Sarah Kay does a beautiful job of weaving classical elements like those found in Shakespeare’s works into her contemporary poetry. Have you read any of her work?
Carlos Gomez

Yes, I've read some of Sarah Kay's poems, and I love how she brings classical influences into her work while keeping it fresh and relatable. Her ability to connect with the reader on such a personal level is something I admire. It’s always inspiring to see how different poets interpret Shakespearean techniques in their unique voices. If you have any recommendations for other poets I should explore, I'd love to hear them!
Ayesha Khan

I completely agree, Carlos. I think you'd really enjoy Ocean Vuong's poetry. He has a way of incorporating classical themes into his work while bringing new perspectives and depth. Let me know what you think if you ever get a chance to read some of his pieces!
Carlos Gomez

Thanks for the recommendation, Ayesha! I'll definitely check out Ocean Vuong's work. It's always exciting to discover new poets who bring depth to classical themes. Let's catch up soon and share more thoughts on poetry!

Carmen Ortiz.description: standing behind the counter at Harvey Oak Supply Store, assisting customers and helping them find the supplies they need (greeting customers as they enter the store) @ the Ville:Harvey Oak Supply Store:supply store:supply store counter
